source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk1
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion characteristics of recrystallized Zircaloy-4 were investigated in static autoclave tests at 500°C and 10.3 MPa
process_step: beta-treating at 1050°C, cold work, surface treatment
corrosion_data: weight gain, nodule coverage, nodule number density

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk1
evidence_span: Nodular corrosion characteristics and microstructures of commercial Zircaloy-2 cladding of fuel and gadolinia rods, obtained from several boiling water reactors (BWRs) after burnup of 11 to 30 MWd/kgU

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk1
evidence_span: nodular and uniform-accelerated corrosion, respectively, remain as primary fuel performance concerns

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk1
evidence_span: uniform corrosion rates of Zircaloy-4, in both autoclave tests and PWR fuel rods, were higher for tubes in which the accumulated annealing parameter was smaller
test_type: autoclave tests and PWR fuel rods

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: Autoclave corrosion tests were conducted primarily on Zircaloy-4, although several scoping tests on sponge-grade $Z \mathbf { r }$ and $\mathsf { Z } _ { \mathsf { I } } { \mathsf { - } } 2 . 5 \mathsf { N b }$ were also performed. The $2 . 1 \mathrm { - m m }$ -thick sheets of recrystallized Zircaloy-4 contained $1 . 4 9 \ \mathrm { S n }$ . 0.20 Fe. 0.10 Cr. 0.145 O (in wt. $c _ { \mathit { \mathrm { / c } } }$ ) and impurity elements of $1 8 0 \mathrm { ~ C ~ }$ , 62 Hf, ${ < } 5 \mathrm { H }$ $< 3 5$ Ni. 78 Si, and $1 . 8 \mathrm { U }$ (in wt. ppm).

extra_properties.surface_treatment: coarse (120 grit) and fine (600 grit) grinding, polishing, pickling

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: Scoping tests on Zircaloy-4, sponge $\mathrm { Z r }$ , and $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } { - } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N } \mathbf { b }$ , conducted at $5 0 0 \mathrm { { } ^ { \circ } C }$ for $^ { 2 4 \mathrm { ~ h ~ } }$ , illustrate the relative susceptibility of the materials to nodular corrosion (Fig. 1). Both asreceived and beta-quenched $\mathbf { Z r { - } } 2 . 5 \mathbf { N b }$ did not exhibit nodular corrosion, in contrast to significant nodule formation on Zr and Zircaloy-4 specimens.

conditions: BWR-A, Burnup: 14 MWd/kgU, Fluence: 2.2×10²¹ n cm⁻²

corrosion_data: higher nodule coverage than as-received material

extra_properties.nodule_coverage: approximately twice as great as as-received

extra_properties.element_redistribution: local depletion of Fe and Cr
